content: My first thought is that your email provider has the capability to address the SPF and DKIM issue, and most will comply if requested, to keep the business. BUT, if the email provider refuses, my suggestion is to use Google Workspace. It's not free, but provides the full service reliability that you would want for a business. It's $6 a month and is at https://workspace.google.com/landing/partners/referral/meet.html

content:
THis is how I would do it. - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to profile folder. Click 'open folder' - exit TB - the account, if POP, is in the Mail folder, otherwise the Imapfolder. - it will appear as Mail\<accountname> with message folders such as inbox, inbox.msf, etc. - COPY the entire <accountname> folder and store on the external drive. - restart Thunderbird - click 'account settings' and then 'server settings' - note the bottom line links to 'local directory'. click the browse button to locate and select the folder you created on external drive. This may require a restart of Thunderbird - restart Thunderbird and all should be okay. Nothing will have been lost in the process. You can now delete that folder on drive c that you originally used as it isn't used anymore.

Reminder: when doing backups, you need to backup both your thunderbird profile and also the external drive folder.
creator: davidsk

content:
I've been looking into this for you since you mentioned the issue in a previous question. I've now found out where you set it, but only you can really know what you need to set.

  • Settings > General
  • scroll to bottom
  • click on 'Config Editor' button
  • In search type: zoom
  • look for : toolkit.zoomManager.zoomValues
  • By default it has these values: .3,.5,.67,.8,.9,1,1.1,1.2,1.33,1.5,1.7,2,2.4,3,4,5

The numbers I've made bold are the ones that used when you use Ctrl++ or 'Zoom' > 'Zoom In' So when you use Ctrl++, you can click on it up to 10 times - increments using 10 stages because there are 10 higher number options. The number 1 is the default reset zoom setting starting point.

  • To Edit click on the pencil icon button

This allows to manually alter the numbers. I tried the following: .3,.5,.67,.8,.9,1,2.5,5,7 After the number 1, I only entered 3 numbers: 2.5 and 5 and 7 Note: use a comma to separate numbers. This had the following effect. When I now use Ctrl++, it increments to a larger zoom quicker and I can only use the Ctrl++ a total of 3 times because there are only 3 numbers after the number 1. Basically less clicking/pressing of keys. There is less choice in the number of variable zoom levels. But if you find yourself doing a lot in Ctrl++ to get to a size you want then this fix will help a lot.

It means you need to consider what numbers you need after the number 1 As this is a personal adjustment setting, you may need to fiddle about with the numbers until you get what you prefer.

  • To save your choices click on the tick icon.

If you ever need to reset back to the default set of numbers then you can click on the far right curved anti-clockwise arrow.

Remember - Before you test your settings Reset everything back to default: View > Zoom > Reset Zoom and you may discover you need to reselect email as well.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: I presume you are referring to a csv file. I also presume that you can create the csv file from whatever is the source, something other than TB. The safest way I have found is this: - add at least one email address manually to the TB addressbook - then, highlight the addressbook, click the three dots to the right, download a csv file. - this is now your master template. open it in a spreadsheet program, alongside an opened csv file from elsewhere. rearrange the columns to match the layout (and first line) that you see in the TB's csv file. - save as csv - you now have a csv file that is perfectly aligned for importing to TB.
creator: davidsk

Hope that's a bit clearer. All the best.

content: Okay, click 'account settings' - the three accounts will show in left sidebar, highlight the desired one for default - slightly lower on left is 'Account Actions' menu. Click that and select 'set as default'

content: One reason for a relay error is when the sending email address and the SMTP email address are different. This is a common occurrence when a user has more than one email address and inadvertently uses the wrong server.
creator: davidsk

content: I don't think the error means the server is wrong, but that you may be using different identifier for email account being sent and email account on the server. If you have multiple email addresses, it might be crossed use of servers; if there is just one email account, it might be error in email address specified on one of the server settings. Not seeing the details, I cannot confirm the issue: I can only provide possibilities.
creator: davidsk

content: First, I have no solution. BUT, I have a guess that the compacting is being interrupted. Look in windows file explorer (assuming you use windows) within the profile to see if there are any files with 'nstmp' in name. If so, those would be partially compacted folders, all of which may be deleted - and would be indicative of the interruptions. And also the frequent attempts to compact. Second, you might revisit your settings for compacting and adjust the size at which you want the compacting to occur. The interruptions might be due to an antivirus program or firewall... but that's beyond my knowledge. Anyway, maybe there's something useful here.
creator: davidsk

I will see how it goes.

content:
Some possibilities would be such as: - do they both communicate with internet identically, such as through the same router? - do they have different antivirus products? the same addons?

I am not an network guru, but those are the kinds of interferences that can cause messages not to be received. Thunderbird is only a messenger.
